body:
Welcome to the LGA's open data publishing course. The following modules will take you through everything you need to know to publish open data. This first module examines the benefits of publishing open data for local authorities, businesses and communities.

In this module you will learn:

  • how publishing and releasing open data can help to empower local communities, improve services and save money
  • the three steps to publishing a basic open dataset
  • how to correctly license your open datasets
  • how open data created a positive impact in local authorities, via case studies
title: Making transparency work for you

body:
Local government is entering its seventh year of spending cuts, with austerity looking to continue until at least 2020. The central government grant is forecast to be reduced by 54% between 2015-2020. 

With decreasing budget and resources, councils will need to find innovative ways to reduce costs while maintaining service quality and meeting their statutory obligations. 

Data plays an important role in making informed decisions. When used effectively, data can lead to new insights that can lead to unexpected benefits.

body:
Data maturity refers to how advanced an organisation is in the way it manages and uses data. It can also describe the journey that the authority undertakes to improve its process of working with data, and evaluate the level of its data practices. 

The UK local government data maturity model measures the levels of data management, data governance and openness, data use, data skills and capability, data awareness and culture. 

If you have thoughts or comments on the data maturity model, why not get in touch?
displayTitle: The UK local data maturity model
title: The UK local data maturity model

_items.title: Data management
_items.body: The data management section of the maturity model assesses how mature the organisation is in the way it gathers and looks after its data. The model measures how advanced the processes are around the collection of data, how well organised the authority's data is and the quality of that data in terms of its cleanliness and freedom from error.

_items.title: Data governance
_items.body: The data governance section of the model assesses how mature the organisation is in how it governs and looks after its data and data sharing. The model measures how comprehensive the governance processes of the data is and how well-developed the open data programme of the authority is.

_items.title: Data use
_items.body: The data use section of the model assesses how mature the organisation's use of data is across its key processes. The model measures how integral data is to the decision-making process for the authority, how much data is referred to during the process of performance, monitoring and evaluation, and the role of data in optimising the work of the authority and automating routine tasks.

_items.title: Data skills capability
_items.body: The data skills section of the model assesses how mature the organisation is in terms of the level of data skills among its workforce. The model measures whether personnel working with data have the necessary skills to do so effectively.

_items.title: Data awareness & culture
_items.body: The data awareness section of the model assesses how mature the understanding of data is among the workforce. The model measures whether all staff have a good understanding of how data sits within the authority and how it can deliver positive results.

body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and& share.

Local authorities have been releasing data for years about councils running democratically and service performance. Recently this has grown to encompass everything from spending, salaries and land assets to the locations of facilities like public toilets.

Publishing open data can bring a range of benefits to your authority. But what are the best arguments to persuade your colleagues and leaders?
displayTitle: What is open data and why should we publish it?
title: What is open data and why should we publish it?
instruction: Click on each of the boxes below to learn more

_items.title: The case for transparency
_items.body: Open data has become key to helping authorities to be transparent and accountable to local people. By being open, councils demonstrate their decision-making and involve citizens in the process. Open data releases are also helping to make council operations simpler to understand and reduce the burden of Freedom of Information requests in popular areas – such as spending, contracts and procurement – and senior salaries.

_items.title: The case for improved services
_items.body:
Authorities need to balance the demands of growing, aging populations with the need to tackle small-scale, local issues, while finding efficiencies and achieving more for less. In an era of unprecedented strain on local budgets, open data offers an opportunity to improve the quality of local services and meet local needs without the outlay of full service delivery. It does this by allowing engaged people to build their own services to complement local offerings.

The availability of detailed open data is essential to enabling new services at the local level, and providing existing services more efficiently.

_items.title: The case for innovation
_items.body:
By growing economies, improving services and building greater transparency, open data allows authorities to identify savings in key areas such as healthcare, education and utilities.

Open data helped to reveal a £200m potential saving for the National Health Service and can be used to highlight similar efficiencies at the local level.

_items.title: The case for social and economic benefit
_items.body:
By publishing key datasets, local authorities support new data-driven enterprises and community groups.

In return, authorities are seeing the benefit of growing local data communities. Not only do these communities attract investment, increase employment and deliver new value to their areas, they also improve people's understanding of their local authorities. Releasing data on mental health, for example, is helping people back to work in local areas.

body:
Open data is usually provided without cost at the point of use.

The traditional justification for this free service has been that authorities produce their open data through the operation of taxpayer-funded services.

However, gathering and maintaining data always has a cost attached to it. For this reason, in some cases local authorities may need to charge the user a fee to cover costs associated with providing quality data as a service, or complying with specific requests. Current guidance states that any cost should be no more than the 'marginal cost' of the data involved. Authorities can charge a fee to cover the costs of supporting a user's data request but cannot charge for raw data under the dataset code of practice for FoI.

title: What about the costs of publication?

body: Follow the four steps below to publish your dataset online.
displayTitle: How to publish your dataset: the basics
title: How to publish your dataset: the basics
instruction: Click on each of the boxes below to learn more

_items.title: 1. Decide what to publish
_items.body: The first step is to decide what you wish to publish. Identify a list of datasets and prioritise them based on the demand from prospective users. Consider whether any of the prospective datasets relate to frequent FoI requests. These datasets can generate substantial efficiency savings and boost transparency. The modules will guide how to publish and improve the openness, quality and consistency of your datasets. Further guidance, information and tools are available on the local government open data pages.

_items.title: 2. Redact the data
_items.body: The first thing you need to do is redact any entries that are exempt from publication. Redaction is the process of removing any sensitive or restricted entries from the data. The redaction process for open data is in line with the existing guidance for your FoI requests. To help you, there is full guidance on redaction in the National Archives Redaction Toolkit.

_items.title: 3. Add a licence
_items.body: Once the data has been redacted, add the appropriate licence. We recommend using the Open Government Licence for all datasets unless there is a specific requirement with the data to use another licence. The next block of this module provides full guidance on licensing your data.

_items.title: 4. Describe your data clearly
_items.body: In order for users to understand the data, think carefully about how you describe your dataset. Consider in particular the title and description of your dataset. Will the audience understand your title? Is it what would be searched for? Do you need keywords for the dataset? Have you described how the dataset is supported and how old data can be accessed? Creating good 'metadata' for your dataset is the first step towards publishing a strong dataset.

_items.title: 5. Publish the data
_items.body: Put the data online in a place that is easy to access and reference from other places such as catalogues and websites. The LGA suggests you create a section on your website called 'open data and transparency' and place your datasets there. Your data also needs to be directly accessible to a machine so it can be automatically searched and linked to from other information on the Web, without needing to accept terms and conditions. To find out more about how to make your data 'machine-readable', visit this guide.

body:
Once you have published your dataset online, the most important thing is to place it under the correct licence. The licence gives you protections and lets data consumers know what they can and cannot do with the data. The licence is also the key property that can turn your published data into open data. While local authorities can choose the licence they place on their dataset, we strongly encourage using the Open Government Licence (OGL) wherever possible for your data. The OGL is a simple, clear licence designed to promote the broadest possible reuse of public data, while protecting the rights of the publisher. The licence is used by all government departments and many other public bodies. Placing this licence on your dataset takes only a few minutes. To apply your licence, follow the link below.
Take me to the OGL page.

In some cases, you may also need to publish location data from Ordnance Survey. Where this is the case, make sure to also check whether the data is covered by the PSMA and whether there are any licensing restrictions in place.

_items.title: Greater transparency: Redbridge Council
_items.body:
Opening data can help authorities to improve how they are perceived and discussed amongst the public. 

Open data helps support transparency and can boost positive press coverage through a growing number of data journalists.

Redbridge Council is among those improving transparency around procurement processes, through the release of their contracts register, purchase orders and corporate contracts.
Take me to the Redbridge case study

_items.title: Improved service delivery: North Somerset Council
_items.body:
Local authorities need to balance the demands of austerity with the need to tackle local issues. With a lack of funding for non-frontline services, many authorities are using open data to improve their outreach and make their delivery more effective.

When detailed open data is made available, it can improve service delivery by engaging local people and businesses, and providing a means for them to contribute to strategies and solutions.

One example of this improved service delivery is the tourism initiative implemented by North Somerset Council, who used historic open data to create a new website supporting the regional tourism economy.
Take me to North Somerset Council case study

_items.title: Support innovation: Leeds City Council
_items.body:
Local governments are reaping the benefits of a growing data economy. For example, in Leeds the Data Mill platform has attracted more than 250 registered datasets including new businesses in tourism, schools and waste collection. Leeds also uses the datasets and resulting services to create a better experience for everyone living in the local area, with services such as the Art Crawl and Leeds Bins improving quality of life across the city.
Take me to the Leeds case study.

_items.title: Generate social and economic benefits: The Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead and Carlisle County Council
_items.body:
Open data allows local governments to generate social and economic benefits in key areas, such as prompt responses to FoI requests and energy use.

Real-time open data helped reduce energy use in Windsor and Maidenhead Council buildings by 16%, saving taxpayer funds and benefitting the local environment. In Carlisle, publication of real-time business rates significantly reduced the number of Freedom of Information requests, improving the process for local businesses and saving the council up to £15,000 per year.
Take me to the Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead case study.
Take me to the Carlisle City Council case study.

In this module we learned how local authorities can find a range of benefits from publishing open data, including cost savings on essential services, the creation of local business incentives and making accountability simpler. We also learned how to publish and license a basic open dataset. However, to unlock the full benefits of open data, you need to publish consistently and to a high level of quality.

In our next module, we will examine what makes a quality open dataset and learn the 12 steps to publishing top-quality data.

Next module
title: Making transparency work for you

body: When looking at the quality of your own data, there are a number of common errors you should check for. There are also some unique challenges for local authorities. Below you can find details of the most common errors experienced by local authority publishers.
displayTitle: Common data quality challenges for local authority data
title: Common data quality challenges for local authority data
instruction: Click the headings to learn more

_items.title: Wrong date formats
_items.body:
Dates can be written in inconsistent ways. Mixed date formats are sometimes simple to spot:

8-sep-2013 vs 8/9/2013

and sometimes less obvious:

8/9/2013 vs 9/8/2013.

An additional challenge is that some applications, like Excel, will ‘guess’ the format when a dataset is opened, which can hide how dates are actually written in the file.

The most common error is the mixed use of American (MM/DD/YYYY) and European (DD/MM/YYYY) formats.

_items.title: Incorrect geographic coordinates
_items.body: When publishing data to LGA standards, GeoX should hold the longitude or easting. GeoY should hold the latitude or northing. The two fields should be included in that order: GeoX then GeoY, from left to right. All georeferences should also use either European Terrestrial Reference System (ETRS) 89 or World Geodetic System (WGS) 84 specification. Some publishers have used previous versions such as WGS 66. Make sure all your geodata is in ETRS89 or WGS84 using this helpful guide.

_items.title: Misspelt headings
_items.body: Column headings (AKA 'field names') in your dataset must precisely match those of the relevant schema. The next module provides extensive guidance on how to locate and use schamas. You need to make sure that the right capital letters and spelling are used to match the schema.

_items.title: Currency notation
_items.body: Price or cost data should not contain a prefix or suffix to the numeric value. For example, some publishers add a '£' sign before a value or 'GBP' afterward. Specify the correct column heading then only put numbers in price or cost fields.

body:
In the previous module you explored how to make transparency work for you. You learned the benefits of publishing open data for local authorities and gained the ability to publish a 'minimum viable' open dataset. In this module, we take a look at some of the ways you can publish better quality data and take you through the 12 steps of publishing a complete, high-quality dataset.

In this module you will learn:

  • The importance of ensuring the data you publish is clean and consistent
  • The major factors affecting consistent publication
  • The 12 steps to publishing high-quality open data

This module also provides useful links to supporting documents and services that can help save time and improve your publication.
title: Making publishing work for you

body:
Open data is designed to be widely usable. Whether for a developer to create a new app, a community group to deliver a better service or for journalists and citizens to hold service providers to account, datasets need to be easy to understand and use.

Publishing good quality data is the key to encouraging greater re-use. Improving the quality of your open data starts before you publish, by cleaning up entries and correctly formatting the data. You can also increase quality by making the data easier for people to find. Finally, through links and promotion, you can generate a larger audience.

Creating better quality data is best done by following a process. Below you can learn why these steps matter before following the complete 12-step process yourself.
title: Why does data quality matter?

body:
The better the quality of your datasets, the better their reception by users. The most important thing is to publish the data in the first instance. You can always improve the quality of your data later. Unfortunately, errors and inconsistencies will always occur in data. Consumers of data are sympathetic to these errors and often willing to help in correcting them through crowdsourcing. Overall, public perception favours those who publish, regardless of quality, over those who don't.

Common errors include incorrect content, duplicate entries, missing data, inconsistent use of abbreviations, spelling mistakes and different data formats. In the next section you can find out how to spot these errors in your own data.

Fortunately there are free, purpose-built cleaning tools designed to deal with messy data. We recommend OpenRefine, which can help you quickly and securely clean large datasets. Unlike Excel and other spreadsheet programmes, OpenRefine allows you to record the changes you make and can even automatically apply cleaning functions to other datasets. Importantly, you can share your record of changes with everyone, including other staff, so that your colleagues can benefit from your cleaning.

To get started with OpenRefine, follow our exercise here.
displayTitle: How can I improve the quality of my dataset for publication?
title: How can I improve the quality of my dataset for publication?

body: Your publishing location provides the gateway for access for your users. When choosing where to publish, start by thinking about how people will search and/or discover the data and consider carefully the following:
title: Choosing where to publish
instruction: Click the headings to learn more

_items.title: Consider a platform
_items.body: Platforms can simplify the process of publishing your data. You may already have a data or content publishing platform that is suitable for your needs. If so you can publish there. If you don't have a platform, you may want to consider some of those used by other authorities to simplify the publishing process.

_items.title: Add an open data page to your site
_items.body: It is a good idea to publish data on your own website, giving it a home. Make a small section and navigation header that will help people to discover your data, and make sure the data section is visible from anywhere on your site.

_items.title: Include links across your site
_items.body: Once the data has a home, people need to find it. It is unlikely that everyone will discover your data by browsing to it directly. Most of your users will search (using a search engine) and hit some page on your (or someone else's) website. It is important to include links to the data on all relevant pages where data has been used to help people navigate their way to the raw data.

body: A related aspect of data quality is how easily people can find it. The following areas all contribute to making your data easier for users to discover.
title: Making data easier to discover
instruction: Click the headings to learn more

_items.title: Provide a consistent location
_items.body:
You should provide your data under a consistent address or URL. This URL should also contain a set of characters that let users locate your data quickly and easily. These common characters are called 'Uniform Resource Identifiers' or URIs. We recommend using a URL for your dataset that uses the LGA's directory of common identifiers to refer to your local authority. You can use the LGA directory to look up the correct code for your authority in seconds. For example, Norfolk County Council has the idenfitier – 'http://opendatacommunities.org/doc/county-council/norfolk'.

You can also add another URL that redirects to the main one if you want to be more informative about the dataset. For example, a dataset from Hampshire County Council about senior salaries might use a URL like 'http://www3.hants.gov.uk/opendata/datasets/senior-salaries.htm', which tells people exactly what the data is about from the address bar.

_items.title: Updating your inventory
_items.body: An inventory is a record of all the open datasets published by a local authority. Inventories are read by automatic harvesters, which constantly search for new or updated datasets to add to collections like the LG open data pages or data.gov.uk. The LG open data pages harvest the datasets published by local authorities across the UK. To allow this harvesting for your dataset, you need to keep your inventory up-to-date. To find out how to publish a good inventory you can navigate to this page. The inventory encourages consistent referencing of datasets across councils to make it easier to find datasets on the same topic or in the same format. Your inventory entry can even be used to automatically update your datasets on data.gov.uk.

_items.title: Registering the dataset in a catalogue
_items.body:
A catalogue is a collection of datasets published by different sources. There are a wide variety of catalogues maintained by different organisations that can automatically harvest your data once good metadata is provided. For authorities, there are two catalogues which are particularly important to add your data to.

The first is data.gov.uk, the UK's national open data portal with a huge community of users. Registration is simple and requires only key metadata information.Click here for a step-by-step guide to registering your dataset

The second is local government open data pages, the community resource for local authority data. Registration with local government open data pages is automatic once you have an up-to-date inventory.

_items.title: Increasing the number of links
_items.body: On the web, links are key. The more links you have to your data from different sites, the easier it will be to find. The best way of achieving greater numbers of links is through exposing your data in other catalogues, like data.gov.uk andhttp://datasets.opendata.esd.org.uk/. Another way to increase your links is to use consistent URLs. By doing so you allow other data to be linked to yours through services like http://opendatacommunities.org/.

_items.title: Optimising your data for search engines and aggregators
_items.body: Most people today will either use a search engine to look for data or visit an aggregator like LG open data pages. Search engines need to be able to find all the relevant details about your datasets. It is important to include good metadata alongside your data and allow search engines to harvest this data and make it easy for people to find your data this way. For an example of how to optimise your metadata for search engines you can look at this simple Google guide.

body: Follow the steps below to prepare your dataset for publication:
displayTitle: How to publish your dataset: Steps 1-6
title: How to publish your dataset: Steps 1-6

_items.title: 1. Decide what to publish
_items.body: The first step is to decide what you wish to publish. Identify a list of datasets and prioritise them based on the demand from prospective users. Consider whether any of the prospective datasets are frequent FoI requests. These datasets can generate substantial efficiency savings and boost transparency.

_items.title: 2. Identify the right schema
_items.body: Once you have a dataset selected, you need to find the right schema to organise and name the column headings. LGA publishes comprehensive schemas and you should use these wherever possible. The next module in this series provides complete guidance on choosing schemas.

_items.title: 3. Prepare the data
_items.body: With your schema selected, you need to prepare your dataset. Make sure all data is under the appropriate column headings, no entries are missing and that you have cleaned the data. Check the 'common data quality' section above for the most common errors to check for. Ensure your dataset is saved in an appropriate format – usually CSV.

_items.title: 4. Redact the data
_items.body: Once your data is prepared, you need to redact any entries that are exempt from publication. Redaction should be applied in line with the existing guidance for FoI requests. Full guidance on redaction can be found in the National Archives Redaction Toolkit.

_items.title: 5. Validate the data internally
_items.body: Once the data is prepared, have a colleague check your work. A new set of eyes will highlight any remaining issues with the data.

_items.title: 6. Add the appropriate licence
_items.body: Once the data has been validated, add the appropriate licence. We recommend using the Open Government Licence for all datasets unless there is a specific requirement with the data to use another licence. See Module 1 for a walkthough of how to license your data appropriately.

body: Follow the steps below to publish your dataset:
displayTitle: How to publish your dataset: Steps 7-12
title: How to publish your dataset: Steps 7-12

_items.title: 7. Pick the publishing location(s)
_items.body: With the right licence in place, it is time to decide where the data should be published. We reccomend creating an open data page on your website. You may also wish to use a publishing platform to simplify the process. Check the section above on 'choosing where to publish' for further guidance. You also need to ensure that your dataset sits under a consistent URL that matches the LGA's resources. See the section above on 'improving visibility' for how to create the right URL.

_items.title: 8. Load and publish the data
_items.body: Time to make the data live on your chosen location(s). Upload the dataset to the website and/or publish it using your platform. Check the dataset is live, can be downloaded by anyone and displays correctly after download.

_items.title: 9. Validate externally
_items.body: Now the data is live, it is time to check that your upload matches the accepted guidelines. Use the LGA Validator to check your dataset matches up to the schema.

_items.title: 10. Update your inventory
_items.body: As soon as you validate your new release with the LGA, you need to update your inventory to make your data visible to harvesters. Check the section above on 'making data easier to discover' for details on how to do this.

_items.title: 11. Register with catalogues
_items.body: In addition to updating your inventory, you need to let data.gov.uk and LGA open data pages know about your new dataset. Again the 'making data easier to discover' section will tell you what you need to do.

_items.title: 12. Promote your work
_items.body: Your dataset is now out there, registered in the right places and of a high quality. The final step is to promote your release. Write a blog or press release to let people know, and promote the new data on social media. If you are aware of any open data user communities, get in touch with them and invite them to try out the new data.

body:
In the previous module, you learned the 12 steps to publishing quality data. In this third module, we examine where local authorities can find the right support to help them publish good quality, consistent open data. We will also look at how you can certify your data to help prove its quality.

In this module you will learn:

  • How standard structures can make your data more useful and consistent
  • How to find and use common schemas for your datasets
  • How to develop your own schema if none is available
  • How to certify the quality of your data

This module also provides useful links to supporting documents and services that can help save time in your publication.
title: Making standards work for you

body:
Open data needs to be simple for anyone to use, whether for a new app, scrutiny, analytics, research or simply to gain a deeper understanding of a subject.

The greatest use comes when the same type of data is consistent across different publishers. An application that tells you where local toilets are should be able to work everywhere, not just in one town. Consistency is also important because it allows you to combine and compare your data with that of other authorities for internal use or sharing.

For publishers in local authorities, making data available in a consistent format is the best way to make your open data useful, both internally and for others.
title: Why do standards matter?

body:
In this third module we examined where local authorities can find the right support to make standards simple and to help them save time and money on publishing data.

In the next module we will explore how to make data work for you.

Previous module Next module
title: Making standards work for you

body: The structure (or schema) of a dataset is a major factor in how useful your data will be to others, as data can be more easily combined and compared if published consistently. You can think of the structure as a set of standard and defined column headings for a dataset. Find out below how to decide which schema should apply to your dataset. For example, INSPIRE provides European-standard schemas for geospatial data in the environment.
displayTitle: What is the best way to structure data consistently?
title: What is the best way to structure data consistently?
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more
mobileInstruction: Select the + sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more

_items.title: What are the benefits of schemas
_items.body:
Schemas help your publishing in two ways. First, a schema helps people combine or compare their data with the same type of data from other publishers, for use in their apps or analytics. Second, a schema saves you time and money when getting data ready for publishing, as you can use one that already exists.

A schema gives people simple access to national services. The Great British Public Toilet Map is a perfect example. The only way a service like this can deliver a national picture of public conveniences is if all the local authorities publish their data to a consistent schema. The map helps to make the experience of finding public conveniences less stressful and also helps to surface the opportunities for greater collaboration between businesses and local authorities.
_items.strapline: What are the benefits of schemas

_items.title: Using an existing schema
_items.body:
The best choice when structuring your dataset is an existing standard schema. Using a standard schema ensures your data can be instantly combined with that of other publishers. The Local Government Association (LGA) keeps a library of popular schemas that it encourages all local government data publishers to use.

By using a standard schema, your open data can be combined with other authorities' releases to build up regional and national overviews.

Using standard schemas is simple: just find the right schema for your dataset, rename your column headings to match and save the result. Under the practical guidance section of this module you will find detailed instructions on using LG standard schemas.

_items.title: Creating a new schema
_items.body: Is there no common schema for the dataset you are publishing? Before creating a new one, why not find out whether there is already some consensus among an existing community of users somewhere (for this, use your favourite search engine). You might need to contribute a new schema but there may be an opportunity to get the community to help. A good place to start is iStandUK, an active community of local government experts who can support the development of a new schema.

body: Consistent publication brings a range of benefits for local authorities.
displayTitle: How to publish your dataset: choosing the right schema
title: How to publish your dataset: choosing the right schema
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more
mobileInstruction: Select the + sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more

_items.title: Core open data schemas
_items.body:
LGA keeps a definitive set of schemas for the datasets that local authorities have to publish under the Local Government Transparency Code, along with other popular open datasets. If you are publishing data in one of these categories, we strongly recommend following the relevant schema. For any of these schemas, alter or add column headings to your dataset to match and save the results:

  • Contracts
  • Land and Buildings
  • Organisation Structure
  • Parking
  • Senior Employees
  • Senior Employee Count
  • Spend
  • Planning Applications
  • Premises Licences
  • Public Toilets

If the dataset you are publishing isn't covered above, scroll right to find out about community schemas.

_items.title: Community open data schemas
_items.body:
If the dataset you are publishing is not covered by one of the core schemas referenced by LGA, you may be able to find a common schema from other local authorities in the community. For certain types of data, common schemas are published by other communities, such as the open data community Github INSPIRE for geospatial environmental data and BS7666 for address and land use. In addition, the LGA schema directory keeps track of over 640 schemas from local authorities across the UK. Simply search the directory for the type of data you plan to publish, and it will show you the common schemas that match.
Take me to the LGA community schema directory


If the dataset you are publishing isn't covered by any of those in the community, it may be necessary to create your own schema. There are some guidelines that can help you to create a good one – scroll right to find them.

_items.title: Creating a new schema
_items.body: You may want to create a new schema if none exist in the LGA directory that matches your dataset and you can't find one from another community. If you need to create a new schema, make sure that it is as simple as possible, links to and references common URI – such as local authority name, services, unique reference numbers (see module 2 for more information) – and that you submit the results back to the LGA community schema directory.

body: Linked data is a type of open dataset that enables specific data points to be joined up with other related data. The simplest example of linked data is a Wikipedia page where you can click on individual words to access related information about them. Linked data works by using a common link called a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI). Using URIs helps data consumers to put data into context.
title: Harnessing the power of links
instruction: Click the headings to learn more

_items.title: Why links are important
_items.body:
Links enable humans and machines to navigate between data sources on the Web.

Linking data points directly to one another allows you to direct a person or machine to a definitive record on that subject, rather than each person maintaining their own record of the data. Linked data functions like an official website by providing everyone with an authoritative resource on the subject. Linked data also saves everyone from duplicating data by sharing a single resource among an infinite number of datasets, using URIs.

_items.title: Finding the right URIs for linking data
_items.body: For a local authority, there are several authorities that can be used to find links for your data. The best one to choose is the LG Inform Plus URI lookup tool, which provides a search for different types of link. Other good sources of URIs include the DCLG Open Data Communities list for local authority codes, ONS identifiers for statistical geographies and Local Government Electronic Service Delivery (ESD) lists for functions and services.

_items.title: An example of linking data
_items.body:
For example, a database of buildings owned by an authority will often have Postcodes/Zip codes against each building in the data records:

Building number: 32
Postcode: SO17 1BJ
Ward: Postwood
District: City of Southampton

With linked data we have no need to replicate data – like ward and district – that are managed by separate authorities. Therefore, the record becomes:

Building number: 32
Postcode:http://data.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/id/postcodeunit/SO171BJ

body:
There is a lot of data out there, much of it messy or difficult to use. ODI Open Data Certificate is a free online tool developed to assess and recognise the quality of open datasets and let users know that any dataset with a certificate meets certain quality criteria. The certificates are an independent quality marque designed to support open data publishers in achieving professional results. The LGA encourages data publishers in local government to make use of ODI Open Data Certificate to reassure data consumers about the data's provenance and sustainability.

Open Data Certificate provides publishers with a range of benefits including:

  • Formal recognition of your data quality
  • A much broader user base
  • Automatic trust in the quality and usability of your data
  • Instant, simple compliance with the best publishing practices
  • Free advice on improving the quality of your data
title: Certifying your data

body: ODI Open Data Certificate considers the legal, practical, technical and social requirements for an open dataset to be useful.
displayTitle: What does the Open Data Certificate look for?
title: What does the Open Data Certificate look for?
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more
mobileInstruction: Select the + sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more

_items.title: Legal requirements
_items.body:
In addition to the open licence, there are three legal requirements that need to be considered.

You must:

  • Protect sensitive information like personal data
  • Preserve the rights of data owners
  • Promote correct use of the data

_items.title: Practical requirements
_items.body:
It is important that open data can be found and relied upon by users.

This means that open data publishers must:

  • Link to the data from their website
  • Update the data regularly if it changes
  • Commit to continue to make the data available

_items.title: Technical requirements
_items.body:
There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data:

  • The format in which the data is published
  • The structure of the data
  • The channels through which the data is available

_items.title: Social requirements
_items.body:
For data use to be sustainable, it is important to have an engaged community of users. The best datasets have:

  • Active support channels
  • Discussion groups and forums
  • Published how-to guides on working with the data

body:
With your dataset published, you need to let users know they can rely on the quality of your work by certifying your results through an Open Data Certificate.

Getting your Open Data Certificate is simple: first, you complete a short questionnaire to assess the level of support you provide for the data. Depending on the answers, the ODI awards a badge that can be embedded on your website to signify the quality level of your publication.

If you are publishing your data in a machine-readable way (for example, by using a data portal like CKAN), the site can pre-fill many of the certificate questions. Just enter the URL on the first page to get started.

Take me to the ODI Open Data Certificate site

title: How to publish your dataset: adding the certificate

body: Publishing against standard schemas can save your authority time and money. The results can also make your data more attractive to developers and other users. The following examples show how some authorities around the UK are already using standard schemas to their advantage.
displayTitle: The benefits of publishing to standard schemas: local authority examples
title: The benefits of publishing to standard schemas: local authority examples
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more
mobileInstruction: Click the + sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more

_items.title: Starting small: Colchester Borough Council
_items.body:
When Colchester Borough Council came to publish open data under the transparency code they were faced with a choice. The council could either spend time and resources developing its own schemas or use an existing one. Calling upon the online open data resources assembled by the LGA, Colchester was able to access the full range of schemas for transparent code datasets, ensuring its results would be clean, simple and compatible with the data of neighbouring authorities.
Take me to Colchester data site

_items.title: Combining planning data: Surrey District Councils
_items.body:
Surrey Heath District Council receives more than 11,500 planning downloads every month. In neighbouring Reigate the number is even higher. Yet people searching for applications in Surrey had to browse 12 different council websites, each with its own challenges. Surrey found that there was no schema for planning data, so it created one in collaboration with Hampshire County Council. They shared their schema openly, and now 12 local authorities publish their data using the schema and provide everyone in Surrey with planning applications through a simple portal. Even better, anyone can take the schema and save time on their own publication of planning data.
Take me to the Surrey Heath case study video
_items.strapline: Combining planning data: Surrey District Councils

_items.title: Building on others: Hampshire County Council
_items.body:
Hampshire County Council published planning data harvested from districts according to a common schema. It developed the schema in collaboration with districts, the LGA and iStandUK. Like Surrey, Hampshire built upon a shared foundation to bring planning applications from the districts together. The result was a visual tool, developed by MySociety, which allows users to interactively search and find planning applications across Hampshire.
Take me to the Hampshire planning explorer
_items.strapline: Building on others: Hampshire County Council

_items.title: Contributing to the community: York City Council
_items.body:
York City Council found a number of the datasets they were publishing fell outside the standard schemas that LGA provided. Wishing to save others the time and money of developing new ones, York opened up its collection of more than 70 dataset schemas for anyone to replicate. The result has been broader adoption of York schemas by other authorities, increasing the compatibility of York data and cementing its position as an open data leader.
Take me to the York schemas page
_items.strapline: Contributing to the community: York City Council

body:
Data is a key resource in local authorities. Used effectively, data can help increase efficiency, transparency and citizen empowerment. However, local authorities, like most businesses, are configured to protect their data resources, even where benefits of greater sharing outweigh the costs.

The key to overcoming this resistance is clear, effective communication of the benefits that better use of data can bring to all staff and councillors. This module will prepare you to deliver a tailored pitch for better use of data.

In this module we'll explore how to:

  • structure the perfect pitch
  • identify different audiences for your pitch
  • tailor your pitch to different audiences
title: Making the case for data

body:
Creating an effective pitch for better use of data requires five elements. When brought together, these create a clear, compelling case for action that can be used when seeking management approval, budgetary and resource support and downstream use and re-use. The pitch should be delivered in 90 seconds or less.

The five components of the perfect pitch are:

  1. What it is – the problem you are solving for your users
  2. What it can do – a tailored description of the benefit
  3. Where it's helped – a relevant, quantified proof point
  4. Why it's best – justification for why it beats other options
  5. What next – a realistic decision that can be taken on the spot

Below we explore each of these components in more detail.
displayTitle: The five components of the perfect data pitch
title: The five components of the perfect data pitch

body: The role of data is to...
displayTitle: What is the role of data within local government?
title: What is the role of data within local government?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Data plays an important role in making informed decisions. When used effectively, data can lead to new insights which can lead to unexpected benefits.

_incorrect.final:

Data plays an important role in making informed decisions. When used effectively, data can lead to new insights which can lead to unexpected benefits.

body: Data is only as effective as the impact that it creates. Here are four ways you can maximise impact with open data.
title: Maximising impact
instruction: Click on the headings to explore more

_items.title: Creating a data culture
_items.body:
Data needs to be at the heart of your organisation to maximise its impact.

A data culture means that data is considered at every decision-making point, at every change in strategy and every new initiative. Data does not just offer a retrospective view of the past, but predicts what is possible for the future.

Councils are conscious that their leadership requires them to develop increased data literacy and analytic skills to truly gain control of effective decision making.

The most successful councils are those that promote data-informed decisions and enable analysts to make better use of data, through training and making resources available.

A data culture needs to be adopted from the top down, bringing the whole team on board in order to maximise impact.

_items.title: Problem-based data use
_items.body:
Significant volumes of data in local councils are collected through administrative duties and the delivery of services. Often this data will not get looked at in an analytical way, unless it is required to solve a problem.

Problem-based data use is when, after a problem is identified, you look at what data needs to be collected or used to solve it.

Problem-based data use is an efficient, cost-effective and proactive way of making the most of data. It enables collaborative data collection. This can start with existing databases held within an organisation, though the more advanced councils are using mobile applications to directly interact with citizens, work with companies collecting the relevant data or use low-cost, distributed sensors.

_items.title: Engaging with the community
_items.body:
Problem-based data use requires data workers in local councils to engage with their community.

Once the main challenges faced by the community are identified, data analysts should work directly with the people within that organisation or field to help solve the problem.

For example, to help inform changes to long-term social work in Newcastle, data analysts worked alongside social workers to look for hypotheses to test and analyse those strategies which offer insight into how best to support families. Analysts take a quantitative role, but also identify patterns of outcome, undertaking deep-dive or case study analysis.

This enables data analysts to test what works best, and develop a data dashboard for social workers to manage their caseloads.

_items.title: Measuring impact
_items.body:
Many councils are taking practical steps to ensure that they are maximising impact with their data work. Measuring this impact is key to ensuring that successes are recorded and used to inform future strategies and services.

When the problem is identified, stakeholders must work together to create measurable metrics that monitor and evaluate impact. If the project fails to meet those metrics, then changing the approach will save time and money. Measuring impact also enables projects to be compared with other initiatives, ensuring that only the best and most efficient methods can be taken forward.

Putting figures against success also helps to produce case studies which inspire decision makers to start building data into policies and processes. Ultimately, this will catalyse better use of data to be adopted across the local government sector.

body:
Increased utilisation of data in local authorities requires the right technology. 

Traditionally, local government has operated in silos. Use of multiple IT systems has made consistent data collection and interoperability more difficult, leading to activities being duplicated and placing an administrative burden on data extraction, cleaning and integration, which needs to be done manually.
displayTitle: Tools that enable better data use
title: Tools that enable better data use
instruction: Explore the different tools councils are using to improve council activities with data.

_items.title: Data integration systems
_items.body:
Legacy systems that don't work together are often a problem in local government. Some local councils are beginning to use specialist software, which can work with multiple legacy systems to integrate their data in one place. This avoids duplication of effort and of data, increasing the efficiency of processes.

Automated data integration also reduces the amount of time consumed by manually processing data from one system so that it can be used in conjunction with another, in order to check eligibility, detect fraud, provide business insights or diagnose service failure.

For example, the Camden Residents Index (CRI) collates data from 16 systems and, as a result, enables the council to reduce administration, provide a more streamlined service and detect fraud.

_items.title: Data portals
_items.body:
Data portals are being developed as a central point for publishing organisational data.

Integrating data from across a range of systems can reduce the amount of times that residents need to repeat or re-enter the same information to different sections of the council. It can speed up the response to applications, enquiries or complaints.

Data portals also allow staff to gain a full picture of a case, including when out of the office and working on a mobile device. This supports better and more assured decisions, particularly in emergencies.

_items.title: The Internet of Things
_items.body:
Internet of Things (IoT) initiatives combine 'things', like buildings or products, with sensors and network connectivity to record and exchange data in order to improve efficiency and accuracy. 

Connecting devices together via the internet has the potential to improve how cities and towns are run on a global scale.

Local authorities can use real-time data from devices and buildings to manage traffic and reduce congestion, match public transport capacity and frequency with passenger demand more accurately, streamline waste collection services, and improve responses to emergencies such as flooding, major accidents, fires or police incidents. 

As well as producing data, IoT devices should also be considered to be consumers and able to react to external factors. For example, integrating road management IoT devices with open data about weather can help them to manage traffic flow in response to external factors, such as fog.

body:
The final element of the pitch is to leave your listener with a clear action.

Listeners want to be able to take action in response to a pitch. Your task is to create an action that allows them to immediately say yes (or no) without needing to think too much about it.
title: What next?
instruction: Click on the headings to explore.

_items.title: On the spot
_items.body: Make sure that your listener can respond to your action on the spot. If they need to consult others or consider your action for a while, it is too big. The ideal is an action that is small, clear, and moves the agenda forward.

_items.title: Clear expectations
_items.body:
Make sure that you set clear expectations to what you are asking. Aspects such as timeframe, resourcing and potential impact should all be central to managing expectations. 

If the listener feels that the timeframe or resourcing constraints limit the opportunity, they may even be able to help. Being open and reasonable will help the listener to become engaged in your pitch.

If your pitch is perfect and there are no problems to be solved then the listener is unlikely to engage with you. You can use the level of listener engagement as an indicator of the potential success of your pitch.

_items.title: Reasonable requests
_items.body: Only ask for budget or time that is reasonable, given the level of expected return. If your requests are unreasonable, you are unlikely to get a positive answer.

_items.title: Examples of good actions
_items.body:
Good actions don't have to be groundbreaking. Examples of good actions include:

  • Getting a date in the diary for a follow-up meeting with more people
  • Commitment to read and respond to a case study relevant to their interests
  • Commitment to send you a feasibility assessment for your solution

body:
You should start your elevator pitch by outlining the problem you are solving for your users. This is known as the value proposition.

The value proposition of a business is central to its business model. This is equally relevant in the public sector.  Without a strong value proposition, the authority does not have justification to deliver its services.

Top tip: think of your value proposition as the abstract or executive summary of your solution. Keep it short, keep it snappy and use a list of three.

For example: better use of data in local government engages citizens in the democratic process, improves services for residents and saves money for the authority.
title: What problem are you solving?

body:
This is the part of your pitch where you can explain your value proposition in more detail. Don't worry about repeating yourself. Repetition is key.

The first time you said your value proposition, you wanted to catch your audience's attention. Now you have their attention, and you've explained the benefits for them, you can explain your solution in more detail.

This is also your chance to justify why your solution is better than alternative solutions. You can give competitive examples if relevant, or examples of where data has been shared with positive consequences to emphasise your point. 

Use a list of three for maximum impact, and remember: repetition is key.
displayTitle: Why better use of data is best
title: Why better use of data is best

body:
Most businesses are configured to protect their data resources. This is equally the case within local government organisations, which have not traditionally been data publishers. It is necessary to revise data management practices to meet modern expectations. This requires support and understanding from all levels of councillors and officers within each organisation.

Clear, effective communication of the benefits is essential to capture people’s imagination and gain their trust and understanding. In this module we have learned how to deliver a tailored pitch for better use of data that highlights value and addresses risks.

We hope you have enjoyed the LGA's open data learning course. If you would like to continue your open data learning journey, why not join a face-to-face course with the ODI?

Previous module
title: Making the case for data

body:
Local authorities are starting to create significant impact from better use of data. In this module we have looked at the impact of data use in local government to highlight where and how exemplary work is being done, and how you can make working with data a core part of your own practice.

But how do you communicate these messages to the rest of your team? In particular, how can you find the right language to speak about data with those you need to support you?

In our final module we look at how to speak about data and, in particular, open data – a trend driving forward the way local authorities work.

Previous module Next module
displayTitle: Making the impact work for you
title: Making the impact work for you

body:
Data is transforming the way that local authorities work. In this module we have looked at why local government is turning to data to solve problems and improve processes. We have also explored tools like the local data maturity model. These can help your authority to improve how it works with data.

But how does data help to create impact for local authorities? In the next module, we will explore how local authorities across the UK are creating impact from their work with data.

Previous module Next module
displayTitle: Making your data work for you
title: Making your data work for you

body:
Many advocates of better use of data use generic arguments when discussing its advantages, but a strong pitch needs to be closely tailored to the priorities and concerns of the audience of the pitch and the decision maker.

In most cases, this can be determined from their professional context. Below we examine five common roles in local government, coupled with the most relevant benefits of better use of data.
displayTitle: What better use of data can do
title: What better use of data can do

_items.title: Policy developers
_items.body:
Policy developers are most likely to be persuaded by the argument that better use of data will enhance their policies. Data-informed policies are more likely to succeed, which reflects well on them and their department or authority.

As many policy developers are elected, transparency and accountability is another key argument. Enabling citizens to hold their local representatives to account improves the reputation of the council.

_items.title: Heads of Customer Service
_items.body:
Improving services is a priority for Heads of Customer Service.

Providing targeted, more efficient services becomes much more achievable through better use of data, for example, in highlighting where a particular service is not working as effectively as elsewhere.

_items.title: Performance Managers and Business Analysts
_items.body:
Data provides the evidence needed by performance managers and business analysts to justify the decisions of a local authority.

Sharing data between departments also increases efficiency by removing silos and the need to replicate the data multiple times.

_items.title: Communications and PR
_items.body:
People who work in communications and PR roles need good news stories that improve a council's reputation and show citizens how their lives are being improved. Improving services and empowering citizens are therefore arguments likely to convince a colleague in communications and PR.

Additionally, all stories must be backed up with evidence. Data provides that crucial evidence.

_items.title: Front line staff
_items.body:
Frontline staff carry the message to the customers. Having streamlined use of data throughout the entire business will give confidence to those delivering services. 

Critically, it is the frontline staff who are most likely to know the problem statement and potential value proposition for better use of data (see the section on 'Why better use of data is best' for more on this). Assisting them to use the data better, be it directly or through other projects, can help improve the efficiency in delivery of services. 

As frontline staff see the impact of the council's work on a daily basis, they are also likely to be persuaded by the argument that data improves the services that they offer.

body: Around the UK, a variety of local authorities are starting to make creative use of their data to achieve impact for their local areas. Look at each of the case studies to learn more about how these authorities apply problem-based data use to make a real difference to their services that they deliver.
title: Case studies

_items.title: Safeguarding young people in Newcastle
_items.body:
Newcastle-upon Tyne City Council has gathered together all data relevant to care for young people into a new service called ChildStat. This gives social workers instant access to an overview of all cases, giving those on the ground a better understanding of the context of their work, related cases and overall social work within the city. 

Through a range of datasets such as truancy, free school meals, 'Looked After Children' (LAC) and grades, the council has been able to develop a clearer picture than ever of what make young residents fall into NEET (Not in Employment, Education or Training).

This work allows planners to better target interventions and monitor the performance of social work teams in the field through access to the ChildStat dashboards.

_items.title: Understanding vulnerable families in Manchester
_items.body:
Manchester City Council worked along similar lines to Newcastle but with a different focus. Where Newcastle looked at the factors that indicate risks to young people for social workers, Manchester focused on the characteristics of a vulnerable family.

For the city's key workers, assessing a family for risk is time-consuming and often an intuitive process. By providing access to a comprehensive picture of the family including engagement with other agencies, key events and family trees, the council is able to significantly speed up the assessment process, improve the outcomes for families and get more assessments booked.

Note: This is an example of shared data, not open data, due to the sensitive nature of the data.

_items.title: Tackling damp in Bristol
_items.body:
Even the most tricky of challenges can be improved through better collection and use of data. In Bristol, the city council understood that damp was impacting the quality of life for many residents, often without the knowledge and means to take action. Using frog-shaped sensors installed in the home, the council is able to monitor damp levels and provide the residents with tips and tools to tackle damp problems where they occur.

Through this collection of data, Bristol is building an unprecedented picture of the damp challenge within city homes and helping residents tackle a common problem through simple, data-informed advice.

Note: This is an example of shared data, not open data, due to the sensitive nature of the data.

_items.title: Keeping the roads clear in Birmingham
_items.body:
Birmingham City Council is one of Europe's largest local authorities.  It maintains substantial numbers of highways. In wintery conditions, keeping these gritted and clear is an essential priority for the council and for over one million of Birmingham's local residents.

Using small sensors attached to lamp posts and issued to highway staff, the city can forecast more effectively when gritting is needed and help to ensure city roads stay clear.

_items.title: Integrating care provision in Suffolk
_items.body:
For Suffolk County Council, as for many other authorities, the challenges of health and social care provision demand a radical re-think in strategy and resources.

Suffolk joined up its health and social care data into a set of proactive measurements of success. Performance against these measures is regularly considered and monitored by all teams working in the area, allowing them to track and improve their own performance and to get a bigger picture of how they fit into the overall health and social care landscape in Suffolk.

The council has been able to better coordinate the different providers, focus resources on problems as they arise and improve the effectiveness of services.

_items.title: Reducing fraud in Camden
_items.body:
The London Borough of Camden has worked to bring data into the heart of its decision-making processes. The authority has introduced data dashboards to monitor metrics and real-time trends rather than simply having reports later. These dashboards have enabled service managers to take action faster, improve quality and reduce the time between a target being missed and a solution being found.

A particular example of this is the Camden Residents Index (CRI) which automates fraud checks for processes like school enrolment and council tax discount claims. The CRI has enabled Camden to reduce the incidence and impact of fraud across its services through better use of data.

body: Better use of data plays an important role in increasing transparency, improving service delivery and reducing costs.
displayTitle: The benefits of better data use
title: The benefits of better data use
instruction: Click on the headings to explore more

_items.title: Transparency and accountability
_items.body:
Enabling the general public to hold government to account, when it comes to spending and performance, leads to more citizen trust and improved performance within governments.

The use of open data portals within councils means that data can be found in one place and be updated when necessary. This makes data not just available, but also valuable and useable.

Multiple local authorities including Greater London Authority, Camden, Bristol, Cambridgeshire, Trafford and Sheffield now have open data portals. Leeds has gone a step further, and is now the open data portal for the region.

_items.title: Improving services
_items.body:
Wider public sector engagement with citizens means that the general public can help shape their communities and services.

Better use of data is essential to improving delivery of services at a local level.

In Milton Keynes, parking sensors have been deployed around the city. This has encouraged drivers to use limited parking more effectively and enabled the council to better understand how parking is used.

The Greater Manchester public service reform planning  (pdf) uses data to model the impact of changes to services. They forecast the outcomes for users depending on combinations of preventative services and test data collected through pilots before implementing changes.

_items.title: Improving efficiency
_items.body:
Better use of data can improve efficiency and reduce costs for local authorities.

Not all data can be shared openly to everyone due to some having a sensitive nature (e.g. containing personal data). However, there are opportunities to share data only between local authorities. This can help reduce the time and cost needed by each individual local authority to collect the same data.

As part of the Troubled Families Programme, over 100 local authorities have shared their family monitoring data to help identify families at risk who require intervention. Intervention has been calculated to save over £7,000 per family in the demand for reactive services, such as the NHS, the DwP and Local Authority social services.

_items.title: Empowering citizens
_items.body:
Better use of data has the potential to empower citizens. 

Publishing data openly enables citizens to hold governments to account. With feedback channels, citizens can contribute to the democratic process. The London Borough of Redbridge developed an online tool to engage residents in the budget process.

body: The next step in the pitch is to introduce real-life examples of where better use of data has already helped. In this section, we explore some existing case studies, grouped by the benefits identified in the previous module.
displayTitle: Where better use of data has helped
title: Where better use of data has helped

_items.title: Transparency & accountability
_items.body:
Open data enables citizens to hold their governments to account.

Open data startup Spend Network analyses public spend data by sector, theme, region and supplier.

In the run up to the decision to proceed with the building of Hinkley Point Nuclear Power Station, Sedgemoor District Council openly published data about the potential impact of the proposed plant as well as proposals to mitigate negative impacts.

_items.title: Improving services
_items.body:
Better use of data can improve services on a local, regional or national level.

Lancashire County Council and Chorley Borough Council are working with other councils and local service delivery partners to standardise online service data to drive apps that make for easier discovery and meet citizens' needs. You can read more about this project here.

Open data published by local authorities was essential in the construction of the Great British Toilet Map, an openly licensed map which shows users where the nearest available toilets are to them across the United Kingdom.

_items.title: Improving efficiency
_items.body:
In Leicester, the Braunstone Blues initiative is reducing the demand on blue light emergency services by consistent offenders. Councils, voluntary groups and emergency services are sharing data and breaking down silos to better understand the needs and aspirations on the citizens who regularly call the emergency blue light services.

Manchester City Council has been working to build a data warehouse across local government and other local public service providers. The data warehouse enables frontline staff to access data in a matter of seconds – data that would take a human hours or days to retrieve from different IT systems.

Calderdale council is creating a standardised Ofsted reporting template to use across all local authorities in the Yorkshire and Humber region. This standardisation means that the data collected will be more usable and help to build a more coherent picture of Ofsted in the area.

_items.title: Empowering citizens
_items.body:
Wandsworth's Open Council makes it easy for residents to see the borough's performance. Residents can directly comment and vote on different performance indicators. 

YouChoose is an online budget simulator that enables citizens to feed into the council's budget priorities. Originally developed by the London Borough of Redbridge to engage its citizens in the difficult decisions that arise from budget reductions, the tool is now being adopted in other authorities across the country.
